answers.answer: Since your EMG demonsrated severe nerve damage in your feet, you can assume the tingling in your feet at least, is not coming from anxiety.  Did the doctor test you for things other than diabetes to try to pinpoint the source of your peripheral neuropathy or does he/she assume it is due to your spinal stenosis?Testing is what happened to a loved one of mine recently with their peripheral neuropathy, and diabetes was the first thing ruled out.  One of the tests done was for heavy metals, which checked the plasma for various proteins and it showed a monoclonal spike in the gamma region.  They then proceeded to do a number of tests to see if, amongst other things, the problem causing the peripheral neuropathy was multiple myeloma, a bone marrow cancer.  We don't have all results back on this yet.Please see private message for extensive info. on peripheral neuropathy.

question: I have had tingling in my hands and feet for 3 years.  I also have spinal stenosis on L3-L4, which occurred at about the same time.  I lost about 1.5 inches in height.I believe the tingling came from anxiety. I had an EMG and my doctor told me that I have severe nerve damage in my feet.  I also have balance problem.  I can walk better with a walker than without, but I like to use a power chair for long distances in our retirement community.  I don’t like to stand for any length of time because of the tingling in my feet.  My feet are weak and I have a very hard time getting off the floor.I just got a form fitting brace and my back does not hurt as much when I stand and when I walk. I do not have diabetic neuropathy.Can the nerve damage in my feet be repaired?
title: back pain and tingling of hands and feet
